“The Future of Electric — Say No More to Polluted Air”

name: Isabella
comment info:
What do I notice?
At the moment, almost all of the 250 million vehicles on the road are powered by gasoline. However, as the graph projects, once Automakers begin prioritizing and shifting to electric cars, more and more of our 250 million vehicles would become electrically run. However, even the number of electric vehicles wouldn't make up a majority until after 2050. So the earlier we convert to electric vehicles, the earlier the entire population would be affected.

What do I wonder?
I wonder what the logistics would be for all automakers to switch to electric vehicles. Also, what would we then do with gas stations all over the country?

How does this affect my community?
The vast amount of gasoline run cars affects my community because of the cumulative pollution that the hundreds of millions of cars that create damage to the environment (such as global warming, air quality, habitat destruction).

Can I come up with a catchy title?
I would title this, “A Project for the Environment — Switching to Electric Cars from Gasoline Cars”.

name: Tony
comment info:
What’s going on in this graph appears to be quite obvious: the projection of electric cars on the road, all the way up until 2050. Do I think it’s realistic? Yes, except for the last panel, and that one’s only going to happen if all sales in 2035 are electric- and I doubt that will happen.
I wonder what the producers of this graph analysed to make a conclusion. After all, you don’t just say “there will be this many EV’s”; and I wonder if the methods they used are susceptible to extrapolation. A long, long time ago, I believe around 7 to 8 years, Elon Musk did an interview with Khan Academy, saying that the predictions of new technologies are shaped like an S-curve. At first, people under-predict, but near full development, they over-predict. I hope that this is the under-predicting part, because EVs are really good for the environment, and being able to see all EVs, or almost all EVs, in my lifetime would be pretty amazing.
Last year, I created a sustainability infographic as a school project (NY Times staff, this is not for profit so please do not censor, and I am sorry if any info is incorrect:https://docs.google.com/drawings/d/1wn5gtd_sn-B5rCKenD9Jq4gM-JA0dUtAZjCMJvWT3wg/edit). It was dedicated mainly towards electric vehicles, and I learned just how green they were- and most of the time, it was a lot greener than critics liked to admit. I would hope to see the predictions in the graph come true.

Headline: Another EV Hits the Dust.

name: Aeryn
comment info:
This graph is showing us the projected use of electric cars between today and the year 2050, with 2050 having two different contingencies. As the graph states, each section represents 250 million cars meaning each individual car represents 637,755 cars. This tells us there are about 1.2 million electric cars on the road or .5% of cars. We can see a steady increase between today and 2035, going from .5% to nearly 11% of cars being electric. This is very different from the near 100% of cars we could see in 2050 if all car sales in 2035 are electric. Even if not all sales are electric by 2035, electric cars will still make up a good number of cars on the road, even if they aren't the majority.
I wonder what initiatives the government can make to push people to buy electric cars. I know there are tax credits for buying electric cars, but what else might we be doing to get to that second 2050 graph where nearly all cars are electric? Do dealers plan on phasing out the selling of non-electric cars after 2035 or will their sales just be diminished?
I know in Oregon many people are eco-conscious. I see lots of electric or hybrid cars around and know many people that own them. I know more and more people in the more "liberal" or eco-conscious areas of Oregon are pushing for the use of all-electric cars. I saw an ad from a major news broadcast talking about trying to make the state go all-electric.
Title: "Green America: The Future of the Electric Car"
